subject: AP Physics 1
expanded_description: Mathematical analysis of position, velocity, and acceleration in simple harmonic motion, including their phase relationships, time dependencies, and graphical representations.
learning_objectives: Derive and apply the kinematic equations for SHM
Analyze phase relationships between position, velocity, and acceleration
Solve problems involving position, velocity, and acceleration as functions of time
Interpret graphical representations of SHM kinematics
Calculate maximum values and instantaneous values in SHM
Apply calculus concepts to SHM analysis

core_concept.principle: SHM Kinematics: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ), v(t) = -ωA sin(ωt + φ), a(t) = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = -ω²x(t), Phase relationships, Maximum values: v_max = ωA, a_max = ω²A
core_concept.explanation: The kinematics of simple harmonic motion follow precise mathematical relationships with position, velocity, and acceleration exhibiting specific phase shifts and proportional relationships.

sections.introduction: Analyzing the displacement as a function of time in simple harmonic motion and understanding the role of amplitude, angular frequency, and phase constant.

key_concept.definition: Displacement function, Amplitude, Angular frequency, Phase constant, Initial conditions, Cosine vs sine forms
key_concept.context: The position in SHM varies sinusoidally with time, characterized by amplitude that determines range, angular frequency that determines rate, and phase constant that determines initial position.

classifications.note: General position: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) or x(t) = A sin(ωt + φ), A = amplitude, ω = angular frequency, φ = phase constant, Initial conditions: x(0) = A cosφ, v(0) = -ωA sinφ

principles.statement: Position in SHM follows specific sinusoidal patterns: Basic Form: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ); A = amplitude (maximum displacement); ω = angular frequency (rad/s); φ = phase constant. Alternative Form: x(t) = A sin(ωt + φ'); φ' = φ - π/2; Sometimes more convenient. Physical Meaning: A: maximum distance from equilibrium; ω: 2π × frequency; φ: determines starting point in cycle. Determining Parameters: From initial conditions: x(0) = A cosφ; v(0) = -ωA sinφ; Solve for A and φ. Special Cases: Release from rest at x = +A: φ = 0; x(t) = A cos(ωt). Passing through equilibrium moving right: φ = π/2; x(t) = A cos(ωt + π/2) = -A sin(ωt). Reference Circle: Projection of uniform circular motion; Radius = A; Angular speed = ω; Angle = ωt + φ. Period and Frequency: T = 2π/ω; f = ω/2π; Relationship to ω. Phase Constant Range: Typically -π < φ ≤ π; Multiple solutions possible; Choose based on physical situation. Position Extremes: x = ±A at cos(ωt + φ) = ±1; x = 0 at cos(ωt + φ) = 0.
principles.application: Write position functions for given conditions. Determine parameters from initial conditions. Calculate position at specific times. Convert between cosine and sine forms. Use reference circle for visualization.
principles.example: Model spring-mass position vs time. Determine pendulum angular position. Analyze oscillator starting from various points.
principles.analogy: Like a Ferris wheel rider's height - it follows a perfect up-down pattern (cosine function) determined by the wheel's size (amplitude), rotation speed (angular frequency), and where the rider started (phase constant), repeating exactly every full rotation (period)

image.caption: Principles of position-time relationships in SHM

worked_examples.title: Determining SHM Equation from Initial Conditions
worked_examples.problem: An oscillator has amplitude 0.20 m and angular frequency 8 rad/s. At t = 0, it passes through x = 0.10 m moving in the negative direction. Find the position function x(t).

step_by_step.explanation: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) = 0.20 cos(8t + φ)
v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ) = -1.6 sin(8t + φ)

worked_examples.final_answer: x(t) = 0.20 cos(8t + π/3) m; Both position and velocity conditions satisfied

step_by_step.explanation: At t = 0.2301 s, v(t) = -1.5 sin(10t) = -1.5 sin(2.3005) = -1.5 × 0.7454 = -1.118 m/s < 0, moving toward negative extreme ✓
T = 2π/10 = 0.6283 s; First negative extreme at t = T/2 = 0.314 s, so t = 0.230 s is before negative extreme ✓

sections.introduction: Analyzing velocity as a function of time in SHM, including its relationship to position, maximum values, and phase characteristics.

key_concept.definition: Velocity function, Maximum speed, Phase relationships, Energy connections, Instantaneous velocity, Speed calculations
key_concept.context: Velocity in SHM varies sinusoidally but is phase-shifted from position, reaching maximum magnitude at equilibrium and zero at the turning points, with direct connections to the system's kinetic energy.

image.caption: Velocity characteristics in simple harmonic motion

classifications.value: Classification based on approaches for analyzing velocity in SHM
classifications.behavior: Different velocity analysis methods provide specific insights: derivative method gives exact time function, energy method relates speed to position, reference circle provides geometric interpretation, and phase analysis reveals timing relationships

examples.explanation: Calculating velocity as the time derivative of position
Determining speed from energy conservation principles

classifications.note: Velocity: v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ), Maximum speed: v_max = ωA, Speed from energy: v = ±ω√(A² - x²), Phase: velocity leads position by 90° (π/2)

principles.statement: Velocity in SHM exhibits specific characteristics: Velocity Function: v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ); Derived from position derivative; Negative sign important. Maximum Speed: v_max = ωA; Occurs at equilibrium (x = 0); Proportional to both ω and A. Speed from Energy: v = ±ω√(A² - x²); From energy conservation: ½kA² = ½mv² + ½kx²; Useful for finding speed at specific positions. Phase Relationships: Velocity leads position by 90° (π/2); When position at extreme, velocity = 0; When position at equilibrium, velocity maximum. Sign Convention: Positive v: moving in positive x-direction; Negative v: moving in negative x-direction; Depends on coordinate system. Velocity vs Time Graph: Sinusoidal shape; Phase shifted from position; Zero crossings correspond to position extremes. Instantaneous Velocity: Specific value at specific time; Can be positive, negative, or zero; Magnitude = speed. Average Speed: Over half period: v_avg = 4A/T; Over full period: zero (vector average). Special Values: At x = ±A: v = 0; At x = 0: v = ±ωA; At x = ±A/√2: v = ±ωA/√2. Reference Circle: Velocity = horizontal component of tangential velocity; v = -v_tangential sinθ.
principles.application: Calculate velocity as function of time. Find maximum speed from system parameters. Determine speed at specific positions. Analyze phase relationships. Use energy methods for speed calculations. Interpret velocity graphs.
principles.example: Calculate oscillator velocity. Find speed at given position. Analyze velocity-phase relationships. Determine timing of maximum speed.
principles.analogy: Like a playground swing - at the highest points (position extremes) you're momentarily stopped (zero velocity), while at the bottom (equilibrium) you're moving fastest (maximum speed), with your speed constantly changing in a smooth, predictable pattern throughout the cycle

worked_examples.title: Velocity Calculations from Position
worked_examples.problem: A particle undergoes SHM with x(t) = 0.08 cos(12t + π/4) m. Find: (a) velocity function, (b) maximum speed, (c) speed at x = 0.04 m, (d) times when v = +0.5 m/s.

step_by_step.explanation: v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ) = -12 × 0.08 sin(12t + π/4) = -0.96 sin(12t + π/4) m/s

step_by_step.step: Speed at x = 0.04 m using energy method

step_by_step.explanation: At t = 0.242 s, v positive means moving in positive direction

worked_examples.title: Energy Approach to Speed
worked_examples.problem: A 0.5 kg mass on a spring (k = 200 N/m) oscillates with amplitude 0.12 m. Find its speed when it is: (a) at x = 0.08 m, (b) at x = -0.06 m, (c) at the point where KE = PE.

step_by_step.explanation: When KE = PE, each has half total energy, so ½kx² = ½(½kA²); x² = ½A²; x = ±A/√2 = ±0.12/1.414 = ±0.0849 m
When KE = PE, KE = ½ total energy = ½(½kA²) = ¼kA²; ½mv² = ¼kA²; v = √(kA²/2m) = A√(k/2m) = 0.12√(200/1.0) = 0.12√200 = 1.697 m/s ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) v = 1.79 m/s at x = 0.08 m, (b) v = 2.08 m/s at x = -0.06 m, (c) v = 1.70 m/s when KE = PE at x = ±0.0849 m

sections.section_title: 3. Acceleration in SHM and Complete Kinematic Analysis
sections.introduction: Analyzing acceleration in simple harmonic motion and integrating position, velocity, and acceleration for complete kinematic understanding.

key_concept.definition: Acceleration function, Phase relationships, Maximum acceleration, Force connections, Complete kinematic analysis, Graphical representations
key_concept.context: Acceleration in SHM is proportional to displacement but opposite in direction, completing the kinematic picture with specific phase relationships to both position and velocity.

image.caption: Acceleration characteristics and complete kinematics in SHM

classifications.value: Classification based on methods for analyzing acceleration in SHM
classifications.behavior: Different acceleration analysis approaches provide complementary insights: derivative method gives exact time function, force method connects to physical causes, proportionality reveals fundamental SHM characteristic, and phase analysis shows timing relationships

examples.explanation: Calculating acceleration as the derivative of velocity or second derivative of position
Graphing position, velocity, and acceleration together to visualize phase relationships

image.caption: Graphical representation of complete SHM kinematics

classifications.note: Acceleration: a(t) = dv/dt = d²x/dt² = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = -ω²x(t), Maximum acceleration: a_max = ω²A, Phase: acceleration leads velocity by 90°, opposite to position

principles.principle: Acceleration in SHM and Complete Kinematic Analysis
principles.statement: Acceleration in SHM completes the kinematic picture: Acceleration Function: a(t) = dv/dt = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = -ω²x(t); Proportional to displacement; Opposite direction. Maximum Acceleration: a_max = ω²A; Occurs at extremes (x = ±A); Proportional to both ω² and A. Force Relationship: From F = ma and F = -kx: a = -(k/m)x = -ω²x; Fundamental SHM condition. Phase Relationships: Acceleration leads velocity by 90°; Acceleration opposite to position (180° out of phase); Complete sequence: position → velocity → acceleration. Special Values: At x = ±A: a = ∓ω²A (maximum magnitude); At x = 0: a = 0; Proportional to -x always. Graphical Analysis: All three functions sinusoidal; Different amplitudes; Phase shifts: position (reference), velocity (+90°), acceleration (+180°). Energy Perspective: Maximum acceleration at points of maximum potential energy; Zero acceleration at points of maximum kinetic energy. Calculus Relationships: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ); v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ); a(t) = dv/dt = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ). Physical Interpretation: Restoring force causes acceleration toward equilibrium; Strength proportional to displacement from equilibrium.
principles.application: Calculate acceleration as function of time. Find maximum acceleration. Analyze phase relationships. Use force-acceleration connections. Interpret complete kinematic graphs. Solve problems using all three kinematic functions.
principles.example: Calculate oscillator acceleration. Find acceleration at specific positions. Analyze complete motion patterns. Determine timing of maximum acceleration.
principles.analogy: Like a mass on a spring - when stretched farthest (maximum position), the spring pulls hardest causing maximum acceleration back toward center; when passing through center (zero position), there's no spring force so zero acceleration but maximum speed; the acceleration always 'chases' the position but always points back toward equilibrium

worked_examples.title: Complete Kinematic Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 0.8 kg mass on a spring (k = 128 N/m) oscillates with amplitude 0.15 m. If it starts from rest at x = +0.15 m, find expressions for and calculate: (a) position, velocity, acceleration functions, (b) maximum values, (c) values at t = 0.1 s.

step_by_step.explanation: Starts from rest at x = +A, so φ = 0; x(t) = A cos(ωt)
x_max = A = 0.15 m; v_max = ωA = 1.897 m/s; a_max = ω²A = 24.0 m/s²

image.caption: Complete analysis of position, velocity, and acceleration

worked_examples.title: Phase Relationship Analysis
worked_examples.problem: For an oscillator with x(t) = 0.10 cos(8t - π/3) m, determine: (a) phase of velocity relative to position, (b) phase of acceleration relative to position, (c) time between position maximum and velocity maximum.

step_by_step.explanation: Velocity leads position by 90° (π/2); Acceleration leads position by 180° (π)

step_by_step.step: Phase of velocity relative to position
step_by_step.explanation: v(t) = -ωA sin(ωt + φ) = ωA cos(ωt + φ + π/2); So velocity leads position by π/2

step_by_step.step: Phase of acceleration relative to position
step_by_step.explanation: a(t) = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = ω²A cos(ωt + φ + π); So acceleration leads position by π (opposite phase)

step_by_step.step: Time between position max and velocity max
step_by_step.explanation: Position maximum when cos(ωt + φ) = ±1; Velocity maximum when |sin(ωt + φ)| = 1
From cosθ = ±1 to |sinθ| = 1 requires phase change of π/2
Position max when 8t - π/3 = 0 → t = π/24 = 0.1309 s; Velocity max when 8t - π/3 = π/2 → t = 5π/24 = 0.6545 s; Difference = 0.5236 s? Wait, check phase
Position max at t = π/24 = 0.1309 s; Next velocity max when 8t - π/3 = π/2 → t = (π/2 + π/3)/8 = (5π/6)/8 = 5π/48 = 0.3272 s; Difference = 0.1963 s ✓
After reaching maximum position, it takes T/4 time to reach maximum speed

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Velocity leads position by 90°, (b) Acceleration leads position by 180° (opposite phase), (c) Time between position max and velocity max = 0.196 s = T/4

common_misconceptions: Thinking velocity is maximum when acceleration is maximum
Believing acceleration is zero when velocity is maximum
Confusing the phase relationships between position, velocity, and acceleration
Thinking the velocity function has the same phase as position
Believing acceleration can be in the same direction as displacement
Confusing angular frequency with regular frequency
Thinking the phase constant affects the period or amplitude
summary: The kinematics of simple harmonic motion are completely described by sinusoidal functions for position, velocity, and acceleration. Position follows x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ), velocity is its derivative v(t) = -ωA sin(ωt + φ), and acceleration is a(t) = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = -ω²x(t). Key relationships include: velocity leads position by 90°, acceleration leads position by 180° (is always opposite to displacement), maximum speed v_max = ωA occurs at equilibrium, and maximum acceleration a_max = ω²A occurs at the extremes. These relationships form a complete kinematic description that applies to all simple harmonic oscillators regardless of their specific physical implementation.
